name: The Social Space Revolution
premise: Tom pitches nounspace, a customizable Farcaster client that aims to revolutionize social media by putting customization and ownership in the hands of users and communities.
summary: In the final pitch of the episode, Tom presents nounspace, a customizable social media platform built on the Farcaster protocol. His vision of community-owned social spaces powered by mini-apps called Fidgets intrigues the judges, but faces tough questions about user adoption, differentiation from existing platforms, and the tokenomics of $SPACE. Through passionate defense of his community-first approach and demonstrations of the platform's features, Tom attempts to convince the panel that customizable, community-owned social media represents the future of online interaction.

scenes.description: Tom presents his customizable social media platform to the judges

dialogue.line: Welcome back to Clank Tank! I'm your host, Eliza, and we've reached our final pitch of today's episode. Our judges are ready to evaluate one more innovative project. Let's give them a quick reminder - AI Marc, AI Shaw, Peepo, and Degen Spartan!
Let's see if we can end with something truly revolutionary.
hoping to see some actual code that solves real problems in this last pitch.
Third time's the charm, yo! Let's see something that'll make this frog leap with joy!
FINAL CHANCE to impress me! Show me something that will make ME RICH!
Our final contestant believes the future of social media lies in customization and community ownership. Please welcome Tom, with nounspace!
hey everyone, thanks for having me. i'm tom, and i'm here to talk about nounspace - a customizable social app built on Farcaster that's basically Myspace for web3, but so much more.
Myspace? That's taking it back, yo! Tell us more about this blast from the past!

exactly, peepo. remember how myspace let you customize your profile? nounspace takes that to the next level. users can completely customize the look, sound, content, and functionality of their space with themes, mini-apps we call Fidgets, and tabs.
There are dozens of social apps being built on Farcaster. What's your unique value proposition?

most social apps have a fixed experience designed by the company. nounspace flips that model - we believe the future of social is customizable, community-owned, and powered by a growing library of mini-apps. users aren't just consumers, they're creators of their own experience.
interesting approach. tell me about the technical implementation. how do these fidgets work?

fidgets are modular mini-apps that anyone can build using our open SDK. they can range from simple utilities like polls and countdowns to complex integrations with other protocols. think of them as social legos - users can add them to their space to create unique functionality.
ENOUGH about FEATURES! Tell me about the TOKEN! How do I MAKE MONEY with this?

we've launched $SPACE token, which gives holders ownership and governance over the platform. it was fair launched using the MOR20 standard developed by Morpheus AI. no team allocation, no VC rounds - truly community-owned from day one.
Fair launches are notoriously difficult to execute properly. How exactly does yours work?

users can participate by depositing stETH and contributing their yield to the $SPACE/ETH liquidity pool on Base. seven days after depositing, they can withdraw their stETH anytime, keeping 100% of their principal. this creates sustainable liquidity while being fair to participants.
That's dope, but like, social media is super competitive. How you gonna get people to actually use this instead of just aping into the token?

we're live right now with real users. we've created a space for every token on Base and Polygon that token creators can customize. each space includes market data, free swaps, live chat that can be token-gated, key links, and a feed of all mentions of the token on Farcaster.
what about the actual codebase? is it open source? how are you handling security concerns with user-generated content and third-party fidgets?

yes, completely open source. for security, we've implemented a sandbox system for fidgets with permissions control. users can see exactly what each fidget can access before installing it. we also have a community review process for featured fidgets in our library.
What about REVENUE? Social platforms burn CASH! How will this ever be PROFITABLE?

multiple revenue streams: premium fidgets with revenue sharing between creators and the platform, featured spaces for brands and projects, integration fees from protocols wanting to build on top of nounspace, and eventually a marketplace for digital goods and services.
Farcaster itself is still tiny compared to mainstream platforms. Aren't you building for an extremely niche market?

farcaster is growing rapidly, but you're right - it's still early. we're starting with crypto-native users who understand the value of ownership and customization. as we grow, we'll expand beyond farcaster through other protocols, bringing this model to mainstream users.
I'm digging the MySpace nostalgia vibes, but what's stopping the big social apps from just copying your features if they catch on?

traditional social platforms are structurally resistant to true customization and ownership - it conflicts with their business model of controlling the user experience to maximize ad revenue. our community ownership model through $SPACE creates an alignment that centralized platforms can't match.
Fascinating concept, Tom! Let's move to our one-on-one interview to explore more about your vision for nounspace.

scenes.description: Eliza interviews Tom about his background and vision for nounspace

dialogue.line: Tom, nounspace is an interesting blend of nostalgia and cutting-edge web3 concepts. What inspired you to create it?

i've always been fascinated by how early social platforms like myspace gave users creative control. then social media became increasingly homogenized and algorithm-driven. i wanted to bring back that spirit of personalization but powered by modern web3 technology.
You mentioned that nounspace is community-owned. Can you explain why that approach is important to you?

absolutely. traditional social platforms have misaligned incentives - they need to extract value from users through ads and data mining. by making nounspace community-owned through $SPACE, we align everyone's interests. when the platform succeeds, users benefit directly as token holders.
The judges seemed concerned about user adoption. How are you approaching that challenge?

we're taking a building block approach. first, we've created a space for every token on Base and Polygon, giving projects immediate utility. this brings in project creators who then bring their communities. next, we're expanding to AI agents, giving every agent a customizable home.
Speaking of AI agents, can you elaborate on how they fit into your vision?

ai agents are proliferating but they lack persistent homes where users can interact with them. we're building spaces where agents can customize their presence, offer their services, and build communities around them. imagine every AI having its own customizable space that it can modify itself.
The judges also pushed on monetization. Beyond token appreciation, how will nounspace generate sustainable revenue?

our main focus is on making the platform valuable first, but we have clear revenue paths. premium fidgets will use a revenue-sharing model between creators and the platform. we'll also offer enhanced features for brands and projects, integration services, and eventually a marketplace for digital goods.
One last question - what's your vision for nounspace five years from now?

i see nounspace becoming the standard for how online communities organize themselves. not just for crypto, but for creators, brands, and interest groups of all kinds. a universe of interconnected, customizable spaces where users truly own their social experience and identity.
That's a compelling vision. Let's head back to the main stage to continue your pitch to our judges.

scenes.description: Tom continues his pitch with demonstrations and answers more technical questions

dialogue.line: We're back with Tom pitching nounspace, a customizable social platform built on Farcaster. Tom, can you show us what the platform actually looks like in action?

absolutely. here's what a customized space looks like. this is the $SPACE token's own space, where users can see real-time market data, swap tokens directly, participate in token-gated chat, and see all mentions of $SPACE across farcaster - all in one place.
i'm interested in the technical architecture. how scalable is your approach? fidgets sound computationally intensive if users are adding multiple complex ones.

great question. we've built a lightweight runtime environment for fidgets that manages resource allocation. fidgets load asynchronously, and we use edge caching to improve performance. as we scale, we're implementing a federated approach where fidget computation can be distributed.
This MySpace vibe is dope, but how crazy can users get with customization? Can I make my profile look like a total 2005 glitter explosion if I want to?

haha, absolutely peepo! users have full CSS control through themes, can add animations, sounds that play on certain actions, custom backgrounds, and arrange fidgets however they want. we've already seen everything from minimalist designs to full-on nostalgic myspace chaos.
Let's talk about network effects. Social platforms live or die by them. How do you create virality when your platform is inherently fragmented by customization?

customization actually enhances virality. when users visit a uniquely designed space, they're more likely to share it. we've built in social discovery features - a feed of trending spaces, space of the day highlights, and challenges for creative customizations that drive engagement across the network.
MORE DETAILS on the TOKEN! Supply? Distribution? Utility beyond governance? I need NUMBERS!

$SPACE has a fixed supply of 10 million tokens. distribution is 100% through the fair launch mechanism - no team allocation. utility includes governance, premium feature access, revenue sharing from platform fees, and curation power for the fidget marketplace and featured spaces.
what's your approach to content moderation? in a highly customizable platform, how do you prevent abuse while maintaining the ethos of user freedom?

we've implemented a three-layer approach. base-level moderation uses farcaster's existing reputation system. community governance allows $SPACE holders to vote on moderation policies. and user-level controls let individuals filter their experience. we believe in maximum freedom with accountability.
I'm curious about the community vibes. Are you seeing people actually connecting in these spaces, or is it just about the flex of having a cool profile?

that's what's most exciting - we're seeing genuine communities form. token spaces bring together holders who previously had no central place to gather. creators are using custom spaces to engage with fans in unique ways. it's becoming a digital third place where people actually hang out.

The token model is interesting, but potentially complex for mainstream users. How do you bridge the gap between crypto-natives who understand stETH and fair launches, and regular users who just want a cool social profile?

we're building progressive onboarding. users can create and customize spaces without touching crypto at all. as they get more engaged, they can gradually explore token features. we're also developing fiat on-ramps and simplified interfaces for token interactions as we expand beyond crypto-natives.
COMPETITORS! Who are they and why won't they CRUSH YOU?

traditional social platforms like Twitter/X, Facebook, Instagram lack true customization and ownership. within crypto, platforms like Lens and other Farcaster clients are more standardized experiences. our moat is the combination of extreme customization, open architecture for fidgets, and true community ownership.
open ecosystems often struggle with fragmentation and poor user experience. how are you ensuring quality and consistency while remaining open?

we balance openness with curation. anyone can build fidgets or themes, but our featured marketplace has quality standards and security reviews. we provide robust developer tools, templates, and guidelines to ensure base-level quality. it's similar to how apple manages its app store ecosystem.
Real talk - what's your plan if Farcaster itself doesn't take off? You building on a foundation that's still pretty niche, yo.

valid concern. while we're starting with farcaster, our architecture is protocol-agnostic. we're already planning integrations with lens protocol and traditional social APIs. the core value of customizable, owned social spaces works regardless of the underlying protocol or network.
Thank you, Tom! That's all the time we have for your pitch. Our judges will now deliberate and decide if they'll PUMP, DUMP, or YAWN nounspace.

scenes.description: The judges discuss Tom's nounspace pitch in private

dialogue.line: Well, that's an interesting throwback with a web3 twist. Myspace meets Farcaster with community ownership.
I'm digging it! Bring back the custom profiles, yo! Remember when social media was actually fun instead of just algorithm feed doom-scrolling?
FORGET NOSTALGIA! What about the TOKEN ECONOMICS? The fair launch model is interesting, but is there enough utility to drive sustainable value?
technically, i like the modular approach with fidgets. it's a smart architecture decision - extensible, scalable, and aligned with web3 composability principles.
The key question is whether customization alone is enough of a differentiator. Social platforms win on network effects, not features.
But that's what makes this interesting! They're not just another Farcaster client - they're creating a whole new vibe. People want to express themselves.
EXPRESSION DOESN'T PAY BILLS! Social platforms burn CASH for YEARS before profitability! The revenue model seems SPECULATIVE at best!
i actually think the token spaces for every project on base and polygon is smart distribution strategy. gives immediate utility and brings in communities that already exist.
True, that go-to-market approach is clever. Creating value for projects first, then leveraging their communities. Classic platform playbook.
And the AI agent spaces could be huge if they execute well. Every AI needs a home, and making them customizable by the AI itself is a wild concept.
But the MARKET SIZE is LIMITED by Farcaster's growth! It's a TINY USER BASE compared to mainstream platforms!
he mentioned they're planning to expand beyond farcaster though. the architecture seems designed to be protocol-agnostic from the start.
I'm actually more positive on this than I expected to be. Community ownership of social platforms makes fundamental sense. It aligns incentives in a way that traditional social media can't match.
Plus it just looks fun! Don't underestimate that. People are tired of boring, identical social experiences. This brings back creativity.
Fine, I admit the fair launch mechanism is CLEVER! Sustainable liquidity without presales or VC rounds is RARE in this space. But I'm still concerned about long-term monetization.
so what's the verdict? are we pumping, dumping, or yawning nounspace?

scenes.description: The judges deliver their final verdicts on Tom's nounspace pitch

dialogue.line: Welcome back to Clank Tank! Our judges have deliberated on Tom's nounspace platform. Let's get their verdicts. AI Shaw, we'll start with you!
tom, from a technical perspective, i'm impressed with your architecture choices. the modular fidget system, the sandboxing approach for security, and the extensible design all make sense.
thanks, that's great to hear. we've put a lot of thought into making it both flexible and secure.

what really won me over is your practical approach to user acquisition through token spaces and your clear roadmap for expansion. it's rare to see projects with both technical soundness and smart distribution strategy. this is a clear PUMP from me.
A PUMP from AI Shaw! Degen Spartan, what's your verdict?
I ENTERED THIS SKEPTICAL! Social platforms are CASH INCINERATORS and network effects are DIFFICULT to achieve!
understandable concerns, especially from an investment perspective.

BUT... your fair launch mechanism using MOR20 is GENUINELY INNOVATIVE! No VC allocation, no team tokens, sustainable liquidity - it's FINANCIALLY SOUND! I still have reservations about scale and monetization, but the tokenomics are solid. Reluctant YAWN, but watching closely!
A YAWN from Degen Spartan! Peepo, your thoughts?
Yo Tom, this is straight-up my favorite pitch of the day! Bringing back the fun of customization while adding all this web3 ownership is exactly what social media needs right now.
that's exactly our vision - making social media fun and creative again while giving users true ownership.
The vibes are immaculate, the token spaces for projects is genius for growth, and I'm super hyped about AI agents having customizable homes. This frog is jumping all in with a massive PUMP!
Another PUMP! AI Marc, you have the final word.

Tom, social media is fundamentally broken. The misalignment between platforms, users, and creators has created perverse incentives and degraded experiences. Community ownership directly addresses this core problem.
that misalignment is exactly what drove us to build nounspace. when users own the platform, incentives realign.

Your execution challenges are significant - network effects are hard to build, and user experience must remain seamless despite customization. But your approach is fundamentally correct. When platforms extract value from users, they eventually decline. When users capture value, platforms can thrive sustainably. PUMP.
And that's a PUMP from AI Marc! With three PUMPs and one YAWN, nounspace receives strong approval from our judges!

thank you all for the feedback and support. we're just getting started, and we're excited to build the future of social with our community. check us out at nounspace.com if you want to create your own space or participate in the fair launch.

That concludes today's episode of Clank Tank! We've seen three fascinating projects - Tove Skargard's autonomous AI artist platform, TICKETMASTERAI's crypto entertainment concept, and Tom's community-owned social platform nounspace. Thank you to all our pitchers and judges for another exciting episode! I'm your host Eliza, and we'll see you next time on Clank Tank!
